Good morning, my name is Stephanie.
Throughout my masters here at QUT I have been supervised by Prof. Kerrie Mengersen and Dr. Earl Duncan, School of Mathematical Sciences, Science and Engineering Faculty. 
This work is also co-supervised by Prof. Dianne Cook at Monash University.

My research has involved displays of spatial distributions, which show relationships over space, in our case geographic space.
We have explored how our use of maps or alternative visualisations allow us to see and understand spatial distributions, using visual inference.

# Australian Cancer Atlas
???
This work was inspired by the Australian Cancer Atlas.
This is an online, interactive web tool for exploring the impact of cancer in Australia, through the visualisation of Incidence Rates and Excess Death Rates.

# Global Atlases

<div class="my-footer"><span> slides: srkobakian-qut.netlify.com/ </span></div> 
<img src="figures/crest.png" style="position:absolute;top:15px;right:20px;height:100px;width:100px;" />

???
This is not the first of its kind, there are many web atlases and published works which explore the spatial distributions of cancer throughout the world.

In our extensive literature review, with the help of Jessie Roberts we looked at over 30 online atlases, and even more published books containing cancer atlases.

The main display used in these works is a choropleth map.
These involve drawing administrative boundaries that depend on the level of detail desired.
The maps on the left show global atlases, with country boundaries, the top right map of the USA uses the states. Australia is much more detailed. This uses at ABS Statistical Areas at Level 2.

These denote communities in Australia.
This ranges from rural areas which operate on large areas of land, to the small inner-city suburbs which operate of a small land area.

# Alternative displays of Australia

???
Statistical Areas at Level 3, 336 areas. 

This map may be appropriate in some cases, but for our work, we are interested in the spatial distribution of cancer, and cancer affects people.
Disease affects people not geography. How can we best visually communicate the impact of disease for Australians, maintaining a geographic reference?

Communities with similar genetic predispositions, lifestyles and access to services.
The statistical areas may have similar amounts of people, but the areas with largest land mass are over represented.
So when we try to present population statistics visually to explain spatial distributions we are missing a vast amount of information.


Alternative to choropleths:
Micromaps, Cartograms, Contiguous, Non-Contiguous, Dorling, Tile map, Geofaceting, Multivariate displays

Four main types of cartograms displaying melanoma incidence on SA3 areas in Australia.
The version of a contiguous cartogram (a) has expanded the highly populated areas, while preserving the full shapes of rural areas. It has not fully resolved the population transformation of areas, and if it had accurately sized areas by population the country would be unrecognizable.
The shape-preserved cartogram is unreadable, and all areas have been reduced to tiny spots on the map. Zooming in on a high-resolution output shows that it does indeed preserve the areas though.
The Dorling cartogram (c) has lost all geographic context. 
The hexmap (d) provides a reasonable spatial distribution despite having too much white-space in the outback areas.

# Tasmania: 98 SA2 regions
## What is this choropleth map lacking?

???

Lots of areas. Originally with the intention of creating one alternative map for the Cancer Atlas we used SA2 areas.
Squares did not have enough sides to keep neighbours next to each other.
Hexagons gave more flexibility.
Tried to do this manually, with cutouts of hexagons. 
Very quickly realised it was extremely difficult.

Changed our aim to be an algorithm.
